name: Guru Nanak Dev Ji
birthPlace: Rāi Bhoi Kī Talvaṇḍī (now Nankana Sahib, Pakistan)
excerpt: Guru Nanak Dev Ji, born in 1469, is the revered founder of Sikhism and the first of the ten Sikh Gurus. A spiritual revolutionary, teacher, poet, and humanitarian, Guru Nanak Dev Ji spread a message of universal love, equality, devotion, and service to God above all distinctions of caste, creed, and gender. His travels and teachings laid the foundation of Sikh thought and practice.

quickStats.label: Disciples
quickStats.value: Bhai Mardana, Bhai Bala, Bhai Lehna (Guru Angad Dev Ji)

quickFacts.label: Birth Place
quickFacts.value: Rāi Bhoi Kī Talvaṇḍī, Punjab (now Nankana Sahib, Pakistan)

biographySections.label: Early Life
biographySections.value: Guru Nanak was born on 15 April 1469 in Rāi Bhoi Kī Talvaṇḍī, a village in present-day Pakistan. From a young age, he demonstrated a contemplative and inquisitive nature, engaging in spiritual discussions and displaying deep compassion for the less fortunate.

biographySections.label: Spiritual Revelation
biographySections.value: At around age 30, Guru Nanak is said to have undergone a profound spiritual experience while bathing in the Kali Bein river, leading to his revelation that 'There is no Hindu, there is no Muslim,' signifying the oneness of humanity and the divine presence in all.

biographySections.label: Travels (Udasis)
biographySections.value: Guru Nanak undertook four major journeys, known as 'Udasis,' covering thousands of kilometers across India, Tibet, Sri Lanka, Arabia, and Persia, spreading his universal message. Accompanied by Bhai Mardana (a Muslim rababi), he engaged in dialogue with people of all faiths.

biographySections.label: Teachings and Compositions
biographySections.value: Guru Nanak’s teachings, enshrined in poetic hymns or 'Bani,' emphasized the worship of one formless God, honest living (kirat karo), sharing with others (vand chhako), and remembering God’s name (naam japo). He denounced ritualism, caste discrimination, and religious hypocrisy.

biographySections.label: Establishment of Kartarpur
biographySections.value: Toward the end of his life, Guru Nanak founded the township of Kartarpur, where he organized a community based on equality, collective worship, and selfless service. This became the model for Sikh religious and social life.

biographySections.label: Final Years
biographySections.value: Guru Nanak lived his final years at Kartarpur, composing hymns and guiding his followers. Before his passing in 1539, he appointed Bhai Lehna as his successor, who became Guru Angad Dev Ji.

spiritualLegacy.description: Guru Nanak shaped a faith rooted in devotion, humility, and social justice. His hymns and teachings are the guiding light for Sikhs worldwide, emphasizing the unity of humanity, remembrance of God, and service to all.
keyContributions: Established Sikhism and its core principles
Composed foundational hymns later included in Guru Granth Sahib
Promoted oneness of God and universal brotherhood
Condemned caste divisions, ritualism, and religious intolerance
Started the institution of langar (community kitchen) for universal equality

modernRelevance.description: Guru Nanak’s message transcends time, inspiring movements for peace, interfaith dialogue, and social equality. His ideals guide millions working for justice and compassion today.
contemporaryImpact: Principles of equality and service inspire social work and humanitarian efforts
His call for universal brotherhood fuels interfaith dialogues
Teachings on honest living and sharing influence ethical frameworks globally
Langar tradition continues to serve free meals to millions, regardless of background

achievements.title: Proclaimed the Oneness of God and Humanity
achievements.description: Issued his epochal declaration after the spiritual revelation at Kali Bein, marking the emergence of a new spiritual movement.

achievements.title: Composed Divine Hymns
achievements.description: Authored poetic compositions forming the basis of Sikh scripture and practice.

achievements.title: Historic Four Udasis
achievements.description: Travelled widely to deliver his message across the Indian subcontinent, Arabia, and Tibet, fostering interreligious understanding.

achievements.title: Established Kartarpur Sahib
achievements.description: Founded a new township as a living example of Sikh community values – equality, labor, meditation, and sharing.

achievements.title: Instituted Langar System
achievements.description: Introduced the free community kitchen where people of all backgrounds dine together.

quotes.original: ੴ ਸਤਿ ਨਾਮੁ ਕਰਤਾ ਪੁਰਖੁ ਨਿਰਭਉ ਨਿਰਵੈਰੁ
quotes.transliteration: Ik onkar satnam kartā purakh nirbha-u nirvair
quotes.translation: There is but One God. His Name is Truth. He is the Creator. He is without fear. He is without hate.
quotes.context: Opening verse of the Mul Mantar; foundation of Sikh theology
quotes.source: ਗੁਰੂ ਗ੍ਰੰਥ ਸਾਹਿਬ: ਜਪੁਜੀ ਸਾਹਿਬ (Guru Granth Sahib: Japji Sahib)

quotes.translation: There is neither Hindu nor Muslim.
quotes.context: Utterance after spiritual revelation, underscoring the unity of all humanity
quotes.source: ਜਨਮਸਾਖੀਆਂ, ਜਵਾਨੀ ਦੀ ਕਥਾ (Janamsakhis, oral tradition)

quotes.original: ਵੰਡ ਛਕੋ, ਕਿਰਤ ਕਰੋ, ਨਾਮ ਜਪੋ
quotes.transliteration: Vand chhako, kirat karo, nām japo
quotes.translation: Share what you have, earn by honest work, and meditate on God’s name.
quotes.context: Summary of Guru Nanak's key teachings
quotes.source: ਗੁਰੂ ਨਾਨਕ ਦੇਵ ਜੀ ਦੀਆਂ ਸਿਖਵਾਂ (Guru Nanak's teachings)

timeline.event: Birth of Guru Nanak Dev Ji in Rāi Bhoi Kī Talvaṇḍī
Profound spiritual revelation at Kali Bein river
Four lengthy missionary journeys (Udasis) across Asia and the Middle East
Establishment of Kartarpur Sahib and communal institutions
Guru Nanak Dev Ji passes away at Kartarpur

historicalContext.period: Late 15th to early 16th century (Delhi Sultanate, Mughal rise)
historicalContext.politicalSituation: Fragmented rule in North India, rise of religious orthodoxy, and intercommunity tensions under Lodi sultans and Mughal expansion.
historicalContext.socialConditions: Rigid caste hierarchies, social exclusion, gender inequality, religious divisions, and prevalence of ritualism in religious life.
historicalContext.significance: Guru Nanak's emergence redefined spirituality, challenged the power of ritual and caste, and advocated an egalitarian community faith based on justice, devotion, and oneness of humanity.

references: Guru Nanak: His Life and Teachings by Roopinder Singh
